In the Drops: Gravel racing docuseries, Dynaplug bar end plugs, nice cycling jewellery and the best playlist yet

After January lasted 84 years, somehow February is already past the halfway point, so let’s not dilly-dally – it’s In the Drops time.

It’s been kicking off on cyclist.co.uk this week with a thrilling line-up of content. We started with a nice Q&A with Lidl-Trek’s Giulio Ciccone and lovely Facebook-triggering explainer on the difference between hooked and hookless rims. We decided that wasn’t triggering enough though, so exposed the internet to deputy editor James Spender’s opinion piece on why weight matters.

A few new product launches have kept things ticking over, with Specialized releasing the new Propero 4 helmet alongside some shoe updates, Factor officially announcing the new Ostro Vam, Trek pushing Bontrager further into the background with some very fancy new shoes and 4iiii bringing out a new dual-sided power meter.

We also had the latest pro cycling news and a look back at André Greipel’s first pro win at the Tour Down Under some 16 years ago.

Onto the good stuff.

Call of a Life Time season two: gravel racing’s free ‘Unchained’ series

The current trend in sports documentaries is incredible, fans have more access than ever to what goes on behind the scenes of their favourite sports and the options just keep on growing.

‘Call of a Life Time’, now in its second season, is focussed on the Life Time Grand Prix, gravel’s biggest racing series in the United States, which takes in seven events over the year including Unbound and is what most current pro gravel riders either take part in or want to take part in. The races aren’t televised, so ‘Call of a Life Time’ not only gives exclusive behind the scenes footage but actually shows action that hasn’t been seen before.

It has most of the big names as talking heads and there’s always a narrative to follow in each episode so it’s not all about the winner (which helps when 2023 was dominated). I thoroughly enjoyed season two and it was a step up in quality from the first.

There are six episodes, each 30-50 minutes long, and the best part: it’s all free to watch on YouTube. That alone is insane in this day and age, and we should probably make the most of it before it ends up on a streaming platform.

  • Watch Call of a Life Time now on YouTube

Dynaplug Covert Drop bar end plugs

If you run tubeless tyres you’ll know about Dynaplug, the excellent tubeless puncture repair tool loved by anyone who has used it. If your sealant isn’t sufficing, simply stick a sufficiently big plug in the hole, give the wheel a spin, do some praying that one plug will do, and cut the exposed end of the plug off. If I can successfully use it, anyone can.

Dynaplug’s Covert Drop takes that technology and sticks it into your handlebar ends (or at least lets you do it). So once you’ve got it in either one or both bar ends, you can be safe in the knowledge you haven’t forgotten to put a Dynaplug in your pocket because they live in your bar ends. The plugs themselves are housed inside the little tube so that stays in while the bit you need comes out easily.

Each plug houses two Dynaplugs (yes it’s a lot of plugging), so you can either have four on the go or two – more likely if you have something else occupying one of your bar ends.

  • Buy a pair now from Freewheel (£134.99)

Studio 51 cycling jewellery

Cycling-themed products can be so tacky and most of us are all stocked up on the good ones (socks and mugs) – nice mugs here if you want more – so when something new comes along that looks actually nice it’s refreshing.

Studio 51 makes cycling-themed jewellery and it’s a lot more classy than that makes it sound. They do necklaces, charms, chains, bracelets and more with fun cycling-related icons.

I personally love the cleat and bidon necklaces, they’re very cool. Studio 51 also makes its products with recycled materials, e.g. the necklace is made with recycled stainless steel.

The Studio 51 name comes from the number worn to Tour de France victories by Eddy Merckx, Luis Ocaña, Bernard Thévenet, Bernard Hinault and Greg LeMond, which is why you’ll find the ’51’ dossard among the icons.

  • Shop now at Studio 51

What we’re into this week: One of the best music years of all time?

While we all know that 2016 was the GOAT year for music, after just a month and a half there have been some absolutely incredible releases and a load more big ones are on the horizon. I took a break from my In the Drops new music playlists last time due to Christmas being a dry period but now my list is utterly stacked with bangers.

Highlights are new singles from English Teacher, Bleachers, Waxahatchee, Maggie Rogers, Kacey Musgraves, Holly Humberstone, Maya Hawke, Matt Champion and Beyoncé, and fantastic new albums from The Last Dinner Party, Mk.gee and Declan McKenna – which I’d recommend going deeper into but stuck a few songs in the playlist.

The best song is the first one though.
